item.name: Windows Memory % Committed Bytes in Use
item.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limitâ€”in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

item.name: Windows PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk Queue Length
item.description: This indicates how many I/O operations are waiting for the hard drive to become available. If the value here is larger than the two times the number of spindles, that means the disk itself may be the bottleneck.

discovery_rule.name: Network interface discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of network interfaces as defined in global regular expression "Network interfaces for discovery".

discovery_rule.description: Discovers logical disks (e.g. partitions C:\, E:\, etc.).

item.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limitâ€”in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

item.name: Windows PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk Queue Length
item.description: This indicates how many I/O operations are waiting for the hard drive to become available. If the value here is larger than the two times the number of spindles, that means the disk itself may be the bottleneck.

item.name: Memory Available MBytes
item.description: This measures the amount of physical memory, in megabytes, available for running processes. If this value is less than 5 percent of the total physical RAM, that means there is insufficient memory, and that can increase paging activity. To resolve this problem, you should simply add more memory.

item.name: Memory Cache Bytes
item.description: This measures the amount of physical memory, in megabytes, available for running processes. If this value is less than 5 percent of the total physical RAM, that means there is insufficient memory, and that can increase paging activity. To resolve this problem, you should simply add more memory.

item.name: Memory Free System Page Table Entries
item.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory Pages/sec
item.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory Pages Input/sec
item.description: This counter includes paging traffic on behalf of the system Cache to access file data for applications. This is the primary counter to observe if you are concerned about excessive memory pressure (that is, thrashing), and the excessive paging that may result. This counter, however, also accounts for such activity as the sequential reading of memory mapped files, whether cached or not. The typical indication of this is when you see high number of Memory: Pages/sec, a "normal" (average, relative to the system being monitored) or high number of Memory: Available Bytes, and a normal or small amount of Paging File: % Usage. In the case of a non-cached memory mapped file, you also see normal or low cache (cache fault) activity.

item.name: Processor % Idle Time
item.description: This is the percentage of time the LP is waiting for work for _Total the average percentage across all LP. This is similar to % Kernel Run Time in the Processor counter set.

item.name: Processor % Processor Time
item.description: This measures the percentage of elapsed time the processor spends executing a non-idle thread. If the percentage is greater than 85 percent, the processor is overwhelmed and the server may require a faster processor.

item.name: Server Work Queues
item.description: Shows the current length of the server work queue for this CPU. A sustained queue length greater than four might indicate processor congestion. This is an instantaneous count, not an average over time.

item.name: Processor Queue Length
item.description: This indicates the number of threads in the processor queue. The server doesn't have enough processor power if the value is more than two times the number of CPUs for an extended period of time.

discovery_rule.name: LogicalDisk Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovers logical disks (e.g. partitions C:\, E:\, etc.).

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk({#DISKNUMLET})\Disk Transfers/sec",300].avg(600,0)}<80 and {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk({#DISKNUMLET})\Avg. Disk sec/Read",300].avg(600,0)}>0.025
trigger_prototype.name: LogiccalDisk {#DISKNUMLET} Read Transfer Latency

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk({#DISKNUMLET})\Disk Transfers/sec",300].avg(600,0)}<80 and {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk({#DISKNUMLET})\Avg. Disk sec/Write",300].avg(600,0)}>0.025
trigger_prototype.name: LogiccalDisk {#DISKNUMLET} Write Transfer Latency

item.host: Template OS Windows Discovery
Template OS Windows Discovery

discovery_rule.name: Network Interface Discovery
discovery_rule.description:
Discovers network interfaces.
The regex 1 Â» (Loopback|Miniport|Microsoft|RAS|QoS|WFP|Tunneling|isatap) [Result is FALSE]
will filter logical interfaces created by the Windows OS.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Network Interface({#INTERFACE})\Output Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: Network Interface {#INTERFACE} Output Queue Length

template.template: Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring
template.name: Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring

item.name: Memory % Committed Bytes in Use
item.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limitâ€”in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

item.name: Memory Pool Nonpaged Bytes
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Memory Pool Paged Bytes
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the paged pool. This is an area of system memory used for objects that can be written to disk when they are not being used. There may be a memory leak if this value is greater than 250MB (or 170MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2020 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: IO Data Operations/sec
item.description: These counters count all I/O activity generated to include file, network and device I/Os. These analyses check when processes are doing more than 1,000 I/Oâ€™s per second and flag it as a warning. These analyses are best used in correlation with other analyses such as disk analysis to determine which processes might be involved in the I/O activity.

item.name: IO Other Operations/sec
item.description: The number of input/output operations generated by a process that are neither reads nor writes, including file, network, and device I/Os. An example of this type of operation would be a control function. I/O Others directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: IO Read Operations/sec
item.description: The number of read input/output operations generated by a process, including file, network, and device I/Os. I/O Reads directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: IO Write Operations/sec
item.description: The number of write input/output operations generated by a process, including file, network, and device I/Os. I/O Writes directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: Processor % C1 Time
item.description: C1 is a power saving mode in a CPU. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C1 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C1 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.

item.name: Processor % C2 Time
item.description: C2 is a power saving mode in a CPU, deeper than C1. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C2 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C2 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.

item.name: Processor % C3 Time
item.description: C3 is a power saving mode in a CPU, deeper than both C1 and C2. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C3 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C3 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.

item.name: Processor % DPC Time
item.description: Determines how much time the processor is spending processing DPCs. DPCs originate when the processor performs tasks requiring immediate attention, and then defers the remainder of the task to be handled at lower priority. DPCs represent further processing of client requests.

item.name: Processor % Interrupt Time
item.description: This measures the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interruptions during specific sample intervals. This counter indicates a possible hardware issue if the value is greater than 15 percent.

item.name: Processor % Privileged Time
item.description: The percentage of time a thread was running in privileged mode.

item.name: Processor % User Time
item.description: This measures the percentage of elapsed time the processor spends in user mode. If this value is high, the server is busy with the application. One possible solution here is to optimize the application that is using up the processor resources.

item.name: Context Switches/sec
item.description: Indicates that the kernel has switched the thread it is running on a processor. A context switch occurs each time a new thread runs, and each time one thread takes over from another. A large number of threads is likely to increase the number of context switches. Context switches allow multiple threads to share time slices on the processors, but they also interrupt the processor and might reduce overall system performance, especially on multiprocessor computers. You should also observe the patterns of context switches over time.

discovery_rule.name: LogicalDisk Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovers logical disks (e.g. partitions C:\, E:\, etc.).

LogicalDisk {#DISKNUMLET} Avg. Disk Write Queue Length

template.template: Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring
template.name: Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory % Committed Bytes in Use
item.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limitâ€”in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory Pool Nonpaged Bytes
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory Pool Paged Bytes
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the paged pool. This is an area of system memory used for objects that can be written to disk when they are not being used. There may be a memory leak if this value is greater than 250MB (or 170MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2020 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Packets Outbound Discarded
item.description: Use this counter to determine if the network is saturated. If this counter continuously increases, it might indicate that a network is so busy that the network buffers cannot keep up with the outbound flow of packets.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Packets Outbound Errors
item.description: The number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted due to errors.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Packets Received Discarded
item.description: The number of received packets that contained errors, preventing them from being delivered to a higher-level protocol.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Packets Received Errors
item.description: The number of received packets that contained errors, preventing them from being delivered to a higher-level protocol.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk Queue Length
item.description: This indicates how many I/O operations are waiting for the hard drive to become available. If the value here is larger than the two times the number of spindles, that means the disk itself may be the bottleneck.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 IO Data Operations/sec
item.description: These counters count all I/O activity generated to include file, network and device I/Os. These analyses check when processes are doing more than 1,000 I/Oâ€™s per second and flag it as a warning. These analyses are best used in correlation with other analyses such as disk analysis to determine which processes might be involved in the I/O activity.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 IO Other Operations/sec
item.description: The number of input/output operations generated by a process that are neither reads nor writes, including file, network, and device I/Os. An example of this type of operation would be a control function. I/O Others directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 IO Read Operations/sec
item.description: The number of read input/output operations generated by a process, including file, network, and device I/Os. I/O Reads directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 IO Write Operations/sec
item.description: The number of write input/output operations generated by a process, including file, network, and device I/Os. I/O Writes directed to CONSOLE (console input object) handles are not counted.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % C1 Time
item.description: C1 is a power saving mode in a CPU. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C1 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C1 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % C2 Time
item.description: C2 is a power saving mode in a CPU, deeper than C1. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C2 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C2 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % C3 Time
item.description: C3 is a power saving mode in a CPU, deeper than both C1 and C2. This counter keeps track of how often the process is able to enter a power saving state when idle. So %C3 Time is the percentage of time the LP is in the C3 state and for _Total the average percentage across all LP.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % DPC Time
item.description: Determines how much time the processor is spending processing DPCs. DPCs originate when the processor performs tasks requiring immediate attention, and then defers the remainder of the task to be handled at lower priority. DPCs represent further processing of client requests.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % Interrupt Time
item.description: This measures the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interruptions during specific sample intervals. This counter indicates a possible hardware issue if the value is greater than 15 percent.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % Maximum Frequency Time
Windows 2008 R2 Processor % Privileged Time
item.description: The percentage of time a thread was running in privileged mode.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % User Time
item.description: This measures the percentage of elapsed time the processor spends in user mode. If this value is high, the server is busy with the application. One possible solution here is to optimize the application that is using up the processor resources.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 % Registry Quota In Use
Windows 2008 R2 Context Switches/sec
item.description: Indicates that the kernel has switched the thread it is running on a processor. A context switch occurs each time a new thread runs, and each time one thread takes over from another. A large number of threads is likely to increase the number of context switches. Context switches allow multiple threads to share time slices on the processors, but they also interrupt the processor and might reduce overall system performance, especially on multiprocessor computers. You should also observe the patterns of context switches over time.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\% Registry Quota In Use",300].last(,0)}>60
trigger.name: % registry Quota in Use

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\% Registry Quota In Use",300].last(,0)}>85
trigger.name: % registry Quota in Use

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\% Registry Quota In Use",300].last(,0)}>60
trigger.name: % registry Quota in Use

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\% Registry Quota In Use",300].last(,0)}>85
trigger.name: % registry Quota in Use

trigger.expression: {Sizing:vfs.file.contents["C:\RepositoryCompression.log",].last()}<30
trigger.name: Compression is < 30

trigger.expression: {Sizing:vfs.file.contents["C:\RepositoryCompression.log",].last()}<50
trigger.name: Compression is < 50

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\Context Switches/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>5000
trigger.name: Context Switches/sec

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\Context Switches/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>15000
trigger.name: Context Switches/sec

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\Context Switches/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>5000
trigger.name: Context Switches/sec

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\System\Context Switches/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>15000
trigger.name: Context Switches/sec

trigger.expression: {Sizing:service_state[RapidRecoveryCore].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Core Crash

trigger.expression: {Sizing:vfs.file.contents["C:\FailedJobsCount.log",].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Failed Job Appears

trigger.expression: {Core:perf_counter["\Memory\% Committed Bytes in Use",300].last(,0)}>80
trigger.name: Memory % Committed Bytes in Use
trigger.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limitâ€”in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\Memory\% Committed Bytes in Use",300].last(,0)}>80
trigger.name: Memory % Committed Bytes in Use
trigger.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limitâ€”in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\Memory\% Committed Bytes in Use",300].last(,0)}>80
trigger.name: Memory % Committed Bytes in Use
trigger.description: This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limitâ€”in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Memory\Cache Bytes",300].last(,0)}>300000000
trigger.name: Memory Cache Bytes

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Memory\Free System Page Table Entries",300].last(,0)}<5000
trigger.name: Memory Free System Page Table Entries
trigger.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Memory\Free System Page Table Entries",300].last(,0)}<10000
trigger.name: Memory Free System Page Table Entries
trigger.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Memory\Pages/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>1000
trigger.name: Memory Pages/sec

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Memory\Pages/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>2500
trigger.name: Memory Pages/sec
trigger.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Memory\Pages/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>5000
trigger.name: Memory Pages/sec
trigger.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Memory\Pages Input/sec",300].avg(600,0)}>10
trigger.name: Memory Pages Input/sec

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\Processor Information(_Total)\% Interrupt Time",300].avg(600,0)}>30
trigger.name: Processor % Interrupt Time

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\Processor Information(_Total)\% Interrupt Time",300].avg(600,0)}>50
trigger.name: Processor % Interrupt Time

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\Processor Information(_Total)\% Interrupt Time",300].avg(600,0)}>30
trigger.name: Processor % Interrupt Time

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server Performance Monitoring:perf_counter["\Processor Information(_Total)\% Interrupt Time",300].avg(600,0)}>50
trigger.name: Processor % Interrupt Time

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Processor Information(_Total)\% Processor Time",300].avg(600,0)}>80
trigger.name: Processor % Total Time

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\system\processor queue length",300].avg(10)}>1
trigger.name: Processor length > 1

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\system\processor queue length",300].avg(10)}>2
trigger.name: Processor length > 2

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\Processor(_Total)\% Processor Time",300].avg(#10)}>70
trigger.name: Processor overload > 70

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\Processor(_Total)\% Processor Time",300].avg(#10)}>80
trigger.name: Processor overload > 80

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\System\Processor Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>10
trigger.name: Processor Queue Length

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\System\Processor Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>20
trigger.name: Processor Queue Length

trigger.expression: {Sizing:vfs.file.contents["C:\RepositoryUsedSpace.log",].last()}>80
trigger.name: Reposiory Full 80%

trigger.expression: {Sizing:vfs.file.contents["C:\RepositoryUsedSpace.log",].last()}>90
trigger.name: Reposiory Full 90%

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Server Work Queues(*)\Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>4
trigger.name: Server Work Queues

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:perf_counter["\Server Work Queues(*)\Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>7
trigger.name: Server Work Queues

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[MSDTC].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Distributed Transaction Coordinator

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[Dnscache].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service DNS Cache

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[eventlog].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Event Log

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[gpsvc].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Group Policy Client

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[Netlogon].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Netlogon

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[netprofm].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Network List

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[nlasvc].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Network Location Awareness

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[RpcEptMapper].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service RPC Endpoint Mapper

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[SamSs].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Security Account Manager

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[LanmanServer].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Server

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[MpsSvc].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Windows Firewall

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[W32Time].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Windows Time

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Discovery:service_state[LanManWorkstation].last(,0)}<>0
trigger.name: Service Workstation

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\PhysicalDisk(_Total)\Avg. Disk Queue Length",300].last()}>1
trigger.name: Total disk length > 1

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\PhysicalDisk(_Total)\Avg. Disk Queue Length",300].last()}>2
trigger.name: Total disk length > 2

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\Memory\% Committed Bytes in Use",300].avg(#10)}>70
trigger.name: Virtual memory > 70

trigger.expression: {Sizing:perf_counter["\Memory\% Committed Bytes in Use",300].avg(#10)}>80
trigger.name: Virtual memory > 80
